subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking
Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I’d like to talk about Rudolf Steiner
and Friedrich
Nietzsche. The video
that was released the day before I will
release
this monologue is about Nietzsche. I
interviewed Adam Crabtree who expressed
his love for Nietzsche and his feeling that
Nietzsche could be,
probably in his mind, the greatest
philosopher who
ever lived. Towards the end of that
interview, for those of you who haven’t
watched it,
I brought up the fact that Rudolf
Steiner, the
mystic, the founder of the movement of
anthroposophy,
about whom I’ve done a previous
interview with Gary Lachman, who wrote a
book about Rudolf Steiner.
I’ll be linking in the upper right
hand corner of your screen
right now to that interview. I think
it’s well worth watching for
those of you who aren’t familiar with
Steiner because he’s a most remarkable
character. One might even say
he’s the embodiment of the Nietzschian
Superman, a person of enormous creativity.
Steiner was trained as a philosopher.
Steiner met Nietzsche. Steiner
was invited to work on the Nietzsche
Archives by Nietzsche’s sister, Elizabeth.
Steiner wrote a memorial essay
three weeks after Nietzsche died
in the year 1900. The essay
was delivered as part of a lecture on
September 13th, I believe it was in 1900
in Berlin. Steiner at the conclusion
of his lecture
says, “Nietzsche won’t be remembered as a
philosopher with original ideas.
He won’t be remembered as the founder of
a new religion or as a prophet.” Adam Crabtree
disagreed strongly with those sentiments.
Steiner concluded by saying
that Nietzsche will be remembered as a poet
who found a way to express his illness
and his suffering through his poetry.
Of course, there was a lot more to it.
Steiner was a deep student of Nietzsche.
He wrote a book which has generally
been translated as,
“Friedrich Nietzsche: Fighter For Freedom”
in English. I think a closer
translation to the original German title
would be something more like
“Friedrich Nietzsche: An Adversary Against
the Spirit of His Age.” Steiner
was also a great admirer of Nietzsche. He saw
in Nietzsche somebody who was willing to
challenge the
basic principles of the age in
which we lived in, and even all ages. Steiner saw
in Nietzsche’s struggle however,
a kind of bitterness. He noted that
Nietzsche had originally written in
praise of Schopenhauer and then turned
against Schopenhauer.
In praise of the composer Richard Wagner
and then turned against Wagner. There was a
certain bitterness to Nietzsche. But Steiner
also understood that Nietzsche
was a heroic figure fighting
against the values that had permeated
Western culture - Christianity
for one, as Adam Crabtree so eloquently
points out. But it was more than that.
Steiner saw that Nietzsche himself
was personally engaged in
a wrestling match with the Antichrist.
That’s a pretty deep thing to envision.
Steiner talks about, he writes
about how he
met Nietzsche at a time, I think it was
four years before Nietzsche’s death but
well after Nietzsche had entered into
a state of catatonia.
Apparently it would have been diagnosed I
think today, as a catatonic
schizophrenic. But Steiner saw what he
believed
was Nietzsche’s Spirit, Nietzsche’s Soul,
hovering above the body, outside the body.
So you see when Steiner met Nietzsche,
Nietzsche didn’t even
recognize that there was another person
in the room.
They couldn’t converse at all. Apparently
Nietzsche was able to eat. He was being fed.
He was being kept alive. But other than that
Steiner saw him engaged in a spiritual
struggle. He saw the spirit outside the body but
still attached to it. He writes, and this is
quite interesting,
he writes that through his spiritual vision
he came to understand that Nietzsche had
had a past lifetime, relatively recent –
I don’t know exactly what he means by
relatively recent
but I assume within a few hundred
years anyway – as a Franciscan
monk, an ascetic, a man who used to
torture himself, flagellate himself,
pray on bare knees on
rocky ground so that his body was in
constant pain. According to Steiner,
when the body is wracked with pain the
spirit is drawn
to it. The spirit wants to be in the body,
wants to, I don’t know,
heal, comfort the body. I’m not sure why. I
would have thought maybe when the body
is wracked in pain the spirit wants to
leave. But
in this case, no.
Steiner goes into some very deep
philosophical arguments about the
difference between being in and out of
the body. But essentially
he’s saying, because Nietzsche spent this
past lifetime
so intensely drawn within his body and suffering
so much agony and so much pain, that on the
one hand
it made him incapable of experiencing love
in the current lifetime. On the other
hand, it made him prone to want to leave
his body.
Nietzsche, according to Steiner, had
a proneness to leave
his body and in leaving his body, his
soul, his spirit,
would wrestle with the Antichrist. Now
there is some dispute amongst
anthroposophists as to who is this Antichrist?
Steiner develops a mythological structure
in which the three great spiritual
forces are: Christ,
who is a balancing force, a force of love;
Lucifer who represents brilliance and
intellect and art and passion, but no
love; and Ahriman who is really dark,
angry. I’ve interviewed my friend Jason
Reza Jorjani about
the Persian deity, Ahriman, the Persian
demon Ahriman, who he describes... I
think he uses the word Angri Manu
in Persian. Angri Manu is an angry
man, you might say. The spirit of Ahriman,
according to Steiner, is devoted to
dragging humanity
down. Now, there’s a lot more than can
be said about
the role of Ahriman in
both Zoroastrian tradition and in the
anthroposophy of Rudolf Steiner. But, in
any case,
Steiner seems to have come to the
conclusion that Niezsche
engaged in a personal spiritual
battle with Ahriman
for which Steiner had great admiration.
But in Steiner’s view he lost the battle
and that’s what led to his supposed
insanity.
In fact, Steiner even goes so far as to
say that Nietzsche’s
out of the body wrestling with Ahriman,
losing the battle becomes a
mouthpiece for the Antichrist, for
Ahriman. Now, as I say, there’s some dispute
as to whether
the Antichrist is exactly the same as
Ahriman.
In any case, that’s
where things end as far as
Steiner’s view of Nietzsche. Then Steiner
sees himself
as continuing the battle.
Furthermore, Steiner apparently,
according to
C.T. Rozell, one writer who has written
about this, an anthroposophist,
suggests that Steiner saw himself, his
own past life, as Thomas Aquinas, the
great medieval philosopher who
brought Aristotle, the knowledge of
Aristotle into Christianity and who was
both a student of and
an antagonist of
the Arabian philosopher Averroes,
who also translated the works of Aristotle
and was very influential in bringing
Aristotle’s works to the West
but had a different slant on it.
Apparently,
Aquinas saw Aristotle’s work as affirming
the importance of human choice, that
our souls evolve. We become who we are
because of the choices
we make. Whereas, I gather the
Arab or Muslim view of Aristotle’s
philosophy was more
materialistic and more fatalistic
than that.
Well, there’s much more that could be
said about all of this but it certainly
sheds an intriguing and interesting
light on the distinction between
an esoteric, metaphysical philosopher
and, of course, a very heroic and
great intellect like Nietzsche.
One wonders: Is Steiner correct in assessing that Nietzsche won’t be
remembered as a great philosopher? No.
Steiner was wrong. I think by all accounts
Nietzsche is remembered today as a great
philosopher. One can point to, in spite
of Steiner’s enormous
contributions and
his creativity I think is practically
unmatched by anyone in the
sense that he was an architect, he was an
artist, he
founded a school of education, he founded
biodynamic farming, he founded Eurythmy,
a school of movement combining
movement and poetry.
Not to mention the philosophical and
esoteric foundations
of anthroposophy and his work in
politics
as well. It goes on and on and on.
The man’s creativity, once it opened
up, I think is practically unequaled.
So I do consider him a candidate
for, if you want to designate someone, who
was Nietzsche’s Superman.
Nietzsche himself
recognized that the Superman
was yet to come
in the future. It didn’t happen in his
own lifetime.
Steiner’s career suddenly blossomed
around the same time that Nietzsche died,
around the year 1900. That’s
when he sort of graduated from
being an
intellect, a scholar, a philosopher,
into being a
world class esoteric teacher.
Well, that’s a lot to ponder, a lot to think
about.
Let me leave you with this question. What
do you think are the
spiritual influences in your life? Do you
ever feel like
you are engaged in any sort of a
personal struggle
with the forces of darkness,
as Steiner and Niezsche apparently both
felt they were? Do you ever feel that you
are aided
or hindered by experiences from
past lives as Steiner suggests he
was aided and perhaps Niezsche
hindered?
And what is the role of love
in your life? Is love something that you
live with? Or live without?
I’ll leave you with those thoughts.
Once again,
thank you for being with me.
[Music]
